wikipedia_page.main:
Admiral of the Fleet Sir Charles Ogle, 2nd Baronet (24 May 1775 – 16 June 1858) was a Royal Navy officer. As a junior officer, he saw action leading storming parties at the capture of Martinique and at the capture of Guadeloupe during the French Revolutionary Wars. He also took part in the landings in Egypt in the later stages of the French Revolutionary Wars.
During the Napoleonic Wars, Ogle commanded of the fifth-rate HMS Unite in the Mediterranean Fleet. He went on to be Commander-in-Chief, North American Station and then Commander-in-Chief, Portsmouth. He also briefly served as Tory Member of Parliament for the rotten borough of Portarlington.

response: ** Sir Charles Ogle, 2nd Baronet, British Royal Navy officer (d. 1858)

Barbarina Ogle was born in 1768. She was the third daughter of Admiral Sir Chaloner Ogle, 1st Baronet (died 1816), and Hester Thomas (daughter of John Thomas, Bishop of Winchester). Her brother was Admiral Sir Charles Ogle, 2nd Baronet. Her sister, Sophia, was married to General Sir Charles Asgill, 2nd Baronet.

:Asgill bequeathed the Thomas Phillips portrait to his brother-in-law Sir Charles Ogle, 2nd Baronet for his family, in perpetuity. "And I give to the said Sir Charles Ogle, for his, my portrait painted by Phillips, and at his decease I give and bequeath the same portrait to his son Chaloner Ogle, requesting it may be preserved and retained in his family." After Asgill's death Ogle wrote to the artist to ask if he could take possession and whether he was still due payment.
*Letitia, married Admiral Sir Charles Ogle, 2nd Baronet

Sir Charles Ogle was a ferry that operated from 1830 until 1894 for the Halifax-Dartmouth Ferry Service. The ferry was the first steamship built in Nova Scotia and the longest serving ferry in Halifax Harbour.Mike Parker, Historic Dartmouth, (1998) Halifax: Nimbus, p. 39  The ship is named for Royal Navy officer Sir Charles Ogle, 2nd Baronet, who served as Commander-in-Chief of North America and West Indies Station from 1827 to 1830.
*Sir Charles Ogle, 2nd Baronet (1775–1858), British Admiral of the Fleet
*1840–1846: Admiral of the Fleet Sir Charles Ogle, 2nd Baronet

The original house on the site was built by William Evelyn in 1722. It was bought by Sir Chaloner Ogle, 1st Baronet in 1773. Sir Charles Ogle, 2nd Baronet inherited the house in 1816 and commissioned Sir Robert Smirke to demolish the west wing and replace it with a new building, built in the Georgian style, which was completed in 1820.
